Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of the experimental setup. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Performance of NO (a) and N2O (b) simultaneous removal over the modified SCR catalysts. Conditions: [NO]in = 250 ppm, [N2O]in = 125 ppm, [NH3]in = 250 ppm, [O2]in = 3%. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of NH3 on NO and N2O simultaneous removal. Table 3 Catalyst VMT 40BiNi/VMT V5+/(V4++V5+) (%) 67.6 59.2 Oα/(Oα +Oβ) (%) 23.6 29.4 Simultaneous removal of NO and N2O over commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst modified with bismuth-nickel oxides Li Zhao Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Han-xiao Wang Investigation Data curation Ming-xin Xu Conceptualization Zi-shu Liu Investigation Qiang Lu Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration ⁎ National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Power Generation Equipment, North China Electric Power University, Beijing 102206, China National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Power Generation Equipment, North China Electric Power University Beijing 102206 China National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Power Generation Equipment, North China Electric Power University, Beijing 102206, China ⁎ Corresponding author. In this study, a series of commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts modified with Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides were prepared and tested for NO and N2O simultaneous removal. It was found that the catalytic decomposition of N2O was dramatically promoted over the modified SCR catalyst with 40 wt% of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides, in which the efficiencies of NO and N2O removal were maintained over 90% and 80% respectively. Besides, the physical and chemical properties of the modified SCR catalyst were systematically characterized. It was confirmed that the doping of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides could promote the oxygen vacancies over the surface of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst, thereby facilitating the decomposition of N2O. Whereas, the surface acid sites for NH3 adsorption and the ratio of V5+ was decreased remarkably with the presence of Bi-Ni species, which partly suppressed the activity of NO catalytic reduction. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords NO and N2O simultaneous removal V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides Oxygen vacancy Acid site 1 Introduction Nitrous oxide (N2O) is one of the important pollutants generated in the combustion process and its global warming potential (GWP) is approximately 310 times higher than that of CO2 [1], which can severely deplete the ozone layer and cause global warming. Stationary power plants are the main sources for the formation of N2O through two ways, i.e., the incomplete combustion in the low-load operation period [2] and the byproduct in the NH3-assisted SCR denitrification process due to the following reactions [3,4]: (1) 4 N H 3 + 4 NO+ 3 O 2 → 4 N 2 O+ 6 H 2 O (2) 2 N H 3 + 2 O 2 → N 2 O+ 3 H 2 O (3) 2 N H 3 + 8 NO → 5 N 2 O+ 3 H 2 O The emission of N2O can be controlled by suppressing its formation and enhancing the after-treatments [5,6], among which the direct catalytic decomposition is considered as the most promising method because of its high efficiency and no secondary pollutants [7,8]. Recently, various catalysts have been developed and used for the catalytic decomposition of N2O, including noble metals, zeolites and metal oxides [9–16]. Parres et al. [17] studied the performance of N2O catalytic decomposition over rhodium (Rh), palladium (Pd) and platinum (Pt) catalysts supported by γ-Al2O3 or CeO2. They confirmed that Rh had the best activity for N2O catalytic removal at about 350 °C, while its performance depended heavily on the redox properties of the supporters. Pietrogiacomi et al. [18] prepared a series of Co, Fe and Ni-exchanged mordenites by the ion exchange method, of which Co-MOR was optimal and the efficiency of N2O abatement could be 100% when the reaction temperature was over 500 °C. Abu-Zied et al. [11] studied the influence of alkali metals (including Li, Na, K and Cs) on N2O decomposition over NiO catalysts. The results indicated that N2O removal was significantly improved with the presence of alkali metals because of their enhancement on the electron-donating ability of nickel. Besides, in our previous study, it was observed that the addition of Bi species could promote N2O catalytic decomposition over NiO by creating surface oxygen vacancies [19]. Furthermore, compared with noble metals and zeolites, metal oxides, especially mixed metal oxides prepared from transition metals such as Bi-Ni oxides, were superior for the catalytic removal of N2O, due to their great advantages in the wide active temperature window, the perfect activities, the high thermal stability and the abundant resources. Whereas, the results introduced above were restricted to the direct catalytic decomposition of N2O individually, while few studies focused on NO and N2O simultaneous removal. As the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with NH3 has been widely utilized for decades, it is a promising and feasible choice to achieve the NO and N2O catalytic abatements simultaneously based on the mature SCR catalysts. V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalyst is the main commercial catalyst for SCR denitrification, but it possessed little activity for N2O catalytic decomposition. Kim et al. tried to promote the performance of N2O removal over V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst by loading Fe-ZSM-5 [20,21]. Their results indicated that the simultaneous abatements of NO and N2O could be realized at the temperature range of 350–500 °C, and the efficiencies for NO and N2O removal were 75% and 42% at 480 °C, respectively. However, the active components for NO reduction and N2O decomposition were confirmed to separate over this modified catalyst. Besides, the poor water resistance of Fe-ZSM-5 also suppressed the further utilization of this modified SCR catalyst. As discussed previously, the mixed metal oxides are quite promising for N2O catalytic abatement, indicating that it is feasible to achieve simultaneous removal of both NO and N2O by modifying the commercial V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalyst with mixed metal oxides. Nevertheless, far too little attention has been paid to develop this kind of catalyst, which is of great theoretical and practical significance for the pollutants controlling during fuel combustion. Therefore, a series of modified SCR catalysts were prepared by loading Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides on the commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts in this study. The performance of the modified SCR catalysts on NO and N2O simultaneous removal was systematically investigated. Besides, a set of characterization methods, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption, temperature-programmed desorption of NH3/O2 (NH3/O2-TPD), temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used to evaluate the physical and chemical properties of the modified SCR catalysts. The new findings could facilitate the industrial application of NO and N2O simultaneous removal over the commercial SCR catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalysts used for NO and N2O simultaneous removal were prepared by doping Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides on the commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst with 1 wt% V2O5, 10 wt% MoO3 and 89 wt% TiO2. Firstly, the precursor of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides was prepared by the precipitation method. Typically, 58.16 g bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi[NO3]3⋅5 H2O) and 9.70 g nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni[NO3]2⋅6 H2O) were dissolved in 255 mL deionized water. 0.2 mol/L Na2CO3 solution was slowly added to this mixed solution until its pH was 9.5. After stirring for 3 h at 40 °C, the Bi-Ni carbonate precipitate was obtained, with the molar ratio of Bi to Ni of 0.1:1, which was consistent with that established in our previous study [19]. Finally, the precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water until the filtrate was neutral. Subsequently, the modified SCR catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method. Typically, 3.59 g ammonium heptamolybdate ([NH4]6Mo7O24⋅4H2O) and 0.37 g ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) were dissolved in 29 mL deionized water with 1 mL ethanolamine as the cosolvent. Afterward, the solution was mixed with 26.12 g anatase TiO2 and a certain amount of Bi-Ni precipitate obtained previously. After being stirred for 4 h and dried at 100 °C for 12 h, the mixture was then calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. Finally, the modified SCR catalyst was ground and sieved to the range of 180–250 µm for the following activity tests. In addition, the unmodified SCR catalyst, abbreviated as VMT, was also prepared through the above procedures without doping the Bi-Ni precipitate. The modified SCR catalysts were abbreviated as nBiNi/VMT, in which BiNi was the Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides and n was the mass percentage of BiNi in the modified catalysts (n was 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 and 60, respectively). 2.2 Activity measurement The performance of NO and N2O simultaneous catalytic removal was tested in a fixed-bed reactor, as shown in Fig. 1. The experimental setup consisted of gas cylinders, mass flow controllers, a quartz reactor, a tail-gas treatment unit and a gas analyzer. In the experiment, the feeding gases, accurately controlled as 3.2 L/min by mass flow controllers, were mixed by the gas mixer and then sent to the reactor, in which the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was maintained at 45,000 h−1. The initial concentrations of N2O and NO in the feeding gas were 125 ppm and 250 ppm, respectively. Meanwhile, the concentrations of NH3, O2 and SO2 were 0–450 ppm, 0–5% and 0–200 ppm, respectively, and the volume fraction of H2O was 0–5%. Besides, the reaction temperatures were 300–450 °C. A Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) gas analyzer (GASMET DX4000, Finland) was used to continuously monitor the concentrations of N2O and NO in flue gas, and the measuring error was ± 1%. The efficiencies of NO and N2O conversion were used to evaluate the catalyst performance. The efficiency of NO conversion over the catalysts was calculated as follows: (4) η= [ N O] in -[ N O] out [N O] in × 100 % Where, η was the NO conversion efficiency (%), [NO]in and [NO]out were the concentrations of NO in the upstream and downstream of the catalysts respectively (ppm). The efficiency of N2O conversion over the catalysts was calculated as follows: (5) η= [ N 2 O] in - [N 2 O] out [N 2 O] in × 100 % Where, η was the N2O conversion efficiency (%), [N2O]in and [N2O]out were the concentrations of N2O in the upstream and downstream of the catalysts respectively (ppm). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The physical properties of the catalysts were characterized by XRD and N2 adsorption tests. The XRD tests were conducted on an X-ray diffractometer with 2θ ranging from 10° to 90°. The N2 adsorption tests were conducted on a physisorption analyzer at about −196 °C, with the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method to calculate the surface areas and the Barrett−Joyner−Halenda (BJH) method to calculate the pore volumes and average pore diameters. Moreover, NH3/O2-TPD, H2-TPR and XPS were conducted to determine the chemical properties of the catalysts, including the capacities of NH3/O2 desorption, the redox properties, and the surface chemical states. Details of these characterizations have been described in our previous study [16]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance of NO and N2O simultaneous removal over the modified SCR catalysts 3.1.1 The effect of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides doping The performance of NO and N2O simultaneous removal over the unmodified and modified SCR catalysts was systematically tested, and the activities are summarized in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2(a), the loading of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides exhibited little effect on NO removal in the range of 300–420 °C at the doping amount less than 40 wt%, and the efficiencies of NO conversion were always higher than 90%. However, as the Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides increased continuously, the catalytic reduction of NO was significantly inhibited and the efficiencies decreased to less than 80% with the loading amount over 60 wt%. This was attributed to the accumulation of excessive Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides on the surface of the catalyst, which could cover the active vanadium species for NO catalytic reduction. The efficiencies of N2O catalytic removal are given in Fig. 2(b). As is shown, the conversion of N2O over the VMT catalyst was almost zero, indicating that the conventional V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 SCR catalyst was incapable of N2O catalytic decomposition. Whereas, when Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides were doped, the catalytic removal of N2O was significantly enhanced, and the efficiencies of N2O conversion increased to over 80% as the loading amounts of Bi-Ni oxides increased to 40 wt%. Besides, the high reaction temperature also favored the removal of N2O over the modified SCR catalyst dramatically. However, as the reaction temperature increased to more than 420ºC, the efficiencies of N2O conversion changed slightly while NO removal was drastically suppressed, due to the catalytic oxidation of NH3 enhanced at high operating temperatures. Therefore, in order to achieve the simultaneous removal of NO and N2O, 40 wt% of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides loaded on the commercial SCR catalyst, abbreviated as 40BiNi/VMT, was optimal in the present study. 3.1.2 The effect of NH3 in the feeding gas Fig. 3 shows the influence of NH3 concentration on the performance of NO and N2O simultaneous removal over the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst. The presence of NH3 exhibited significant effects on both NO and N2O catalytic abatements. When NH3 concentration increased from 0 to 250 ppm, the efficiencies of NO conversion increased to about 91%, while the efficiencies of N2O decomposition decreased from 85% to 75%. With continuously increasing the concentration of NH3, NO reduction was slightly affected, but the conversion of N2O continued to decrease. This indicated that the gaseous NH3 could suppress the catalytic removal of N2O, which was attributed to the competitive adsorption between NH3 and N2O on the active sites of the modified SCR catalyst [21]. Besides, in the process of NO catalytic reduction, NH3 could easily be oxidized to N2O with the presence of O2 [20], which also decreased the efficiencies of N2O removal on this modified SCR catalyst. 3.1.3 The effect of O2 in the feeding gas The effect of O2 concentration on NO and N2O simultaneous removal over the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst was also investigated, which is given in Fig. 4. The presence of O2 could significantly promote the removal of NO. With the absence of oxygen, the conversion of NO was only about 43%, while it increased to more than 90% after introducing O2 to the reactor. With continuously increasing the O2 concentration, the efficiencies of NO removal changed slightly, which were kept at about 91%. This indicated that the excess oxygen exhibited little enhancement on the SCR reaction. Nevertheless, the presence of O2 dramatically suppressed the catalytic decomposition of N2O. When O2 concentration increased from 0% to 5%, the conversion of N2O over the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst decreased by 30%, which was due to the competitive adsorption of O2 and N2O on the active sites of the modified catalyst [16]. In addition, since the desorption of oxygen was the rate-determining step for N2O catalytic decomposition [22], the presence of O2 also suppressed the desorption of O2 formed in the process of N2O catalytic decomposition, resulting in the decrease of N2O removal. 3.1.4 The effect of H2O addition The effect of H2O concentration on the simultaneous removal of NO and N2O over the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst is given in Fig. 5. As can be seen, the presence of H2O slightly inhibited the reduction of NO, because of the competitive adsorption of H2O and NO over the catalyst surface [23]. Moreover, H2O also suppressed the catalytic decomposition of N2O. As the concentrations of H2O increased from 0% to 2%, the efficiencies of N2O conversion decreased from 73% to 67%, which was also attributed to the competitive adsorption between H2O and N2O on the surface of the catalyst [19]. When H2O continuously increased to more than 2%, its inhibition on N2O decomposition was relatively weak, and the efficiencies of N2O conversion were maintained at about 60%. 3.1.5 The effect of SO2 addition The presence of SO2 on the performance of NO and N2O simultaneous removal over the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst is given in Fig. 6. It was observed that NO reduction was changed slightly with the addition of SO2, and the efficiencies of NO removal were maintained about 90%. Whilst, the decomposition of N2O was seriously inhibited when SO2 was introduced. With increasing the concentration of SO2 from 0 to 80 ppm, the conversion of N2O decreased rapidly from 73% to 18%, which was attributed to the sulfation of active sites for N2O decomposition [24]. Besides, as SO2 was increased continuously, the efficiencies of N2O decompostion were kept about 16%. This indicated that the SO2 tolerance of the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst should be further improved. 3.1.6 The stability of NO and N2O simultaneous removal To determine the long-term performance of NO and N2O simultaneous removal over the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst, the stability test was conducted at 390 °C for 10 h, which is shown in Fig. 7. It was found that the efficiencies of NO and N2O removal were maintained steadily at about 90% and 72% respectively in the duration of 10 h, which demonstrated that the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst exhibited a promising stability for the simultaneous removal of NO and N2O. 3.2 Characterization of the modified SCR catalysts with Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides 3.2.1 The textural properties In order to reveal the effect of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides on the crystal structures of the commercial VMT catalyst, the VMT and 40BiNi/VMT catalysts were characterized by XRD, respectively. The results are given in Fig. 8. The diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2, cubic phase NiO and Bi2O3 could be detected over the VMT and 40BiNi/VMT catalysts. Notably, owing to the addition of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides, an additional peak at 63.5º attributed to NiO was determined over the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst [25,26]. This confirmed that the introduction of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides had little effect on the crystalline structure of TiO2 support, which was always kept as anatase. Besides, VOx and MoOx were not detected over these catalysts, indicating that V and Mo species were highly dispersed on the surface of the catalysts [27]. This revealed that the modification of the SCR catalyst by loading 40 wt% of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides would not result in the accumulation of active V and Mo species over the commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. In addition, the influences of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides on the physical structures of the modified SCR catalyst were systematically investigated. Table 1 presented the specific surface areas, total pore volumes and average pore sizes of the VMT and 40BiNi/VMT catalysts. Compared with those of the unmodified catalyst, the specific surface area and the pore volume of the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst were smaller, while its pore size was higher. Based on the XRD patterns in Fig. 8, the crystal structures of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides were kept stable as bismuth oxides and nickel oxides with small grain sizes [28]. Therefore, the doped Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides could easily diffuse and deposit in the micropores of the catalyst, which could block the micropores and cause the decrease of both specific surface area and pore volume [29]. Meanwhile, as the deposition of Bi-Ni oxides exhibited little effect on the structures of both meso and macropores, the average pore sizes of the modified catalyst increased slightly. This indicated that the decrease of NO conversion efficiencies over the modified SCR catalyst could be attributed to the block of micropores by the Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides. In addition, since the doped Bi-Ni oxides were in the stable crystalline structures of NiO and Bi2O3, the performance of N2O catalytic decomposition was facilitated, which was consistent with the activities of the catalysts described previously. 3.2.2 NH3-TPD NH3-TPD tests were carried out to study the performance of NH3 desorption over the catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 9. The presence of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides was negative for NH3 adsorption over the modified catalyst. As described in Section 3.2.1, the Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides blocked the micropores in the VMT catalyst, which covered the original active sites scattered over the catalyst. Therefore, the amounts of acid sites for NH3 adsorption decreased, and the performance of NO reduction was suppressed. 3.2.3 O2-TPD As the desorption of oxygen was the rate-determining step during the catalytic decomposition of N2O, the capacities of oxygen desorption on the unmodified and modified VMT catalysts were respectively studied by O2-TPD tests, and the results are shown in Fig. 10. The initial desorption temperature of surface adsorbed oxygen was about 277 °C for the VMT catalyst, while it decreased to 156 °C for the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst. This indicated that the desorption capacity of the absorbed oxygen was enhanced with the presence of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides, which facilitated the performance of N2O catalytic decomposition [30]. The desorption of oxygen was considered as the rate-determining step for N2O removal, and the free oxygen atoms generated in the process of N2O decompostion should be desorbed at or below the reaction temperature, which was generally 300ºC for the metal-oxide catalysts. Otherwise, the active sites could be poisoned, which further intercepted the catalytic cycle of N2O decomposition [16]. Hence, the amounts of oxygen desorption in the process of O2-TPD tests were calculated by integrating the peak areas below 300 °C in the desorption profiles [22]. The results are given in Table 2. It was obtained that the desorption of oxygen over the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst was much more than that over the VMT catalyst. This confirmed that the SCR catalyst modified with Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides exhibited superior performance of oxygen desorption, which favored the N2O catalytic decomposition. This agreed well with the results in Sections 3.1.1 and 3.2.1. 3.2.4 H2-TPR The redox properties of the unmodified and modified catalysts were evaluated by H2-TPR tests, which are shown in Fig. 11. As for the H2-TPR profile of the VMT catalyst, the peak ranging from 300 °C to 400°C was assigned to the reduction from V5+ to V3+ and the peak located at 700–800 °C was ascribed to the reduction from Mo6+ to Mo0 [31–33]. As for the profile of the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst, the peaks ranging from 300 to 400 °C were ascribed to the synergetic reduction from Ni2+ to Ni0 and from V5+ to V3+. Besides, the peak at 400–500 °C was also attributed to the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 casused by the electron migration between active Bi species and NiO grains [32,34]. The results confirmed that the doping of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides could significantly decrease the reduction temperature of the commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. Besides, compared with that of the VMT catalyst, the peak areas of the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst were much larger, which indicated that the amounts of H2 desorption increased with the presence of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides [34]. As determined by the XRD patterns, the Bi-Ni oxides were kept stable over the catalyst surface, and their strong reducing capacity could significantly promote the redox performance of the modified catalyst. Therefore, the catalytic decomposition of N2O over the modified catalyst was improved. 3.2.5 XPS studies The XPS tests were carried out to determine the surface chemical states of active V species in the catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 12. The peaks at 515.8 eV and 516.8 eV were ascribed to V4+ and V5+ [35], indicating that the main valence states of V species were V4+ and V5+. Besides, V5+/(V4++V5+) values were also calculated to evaluate the reducing capacity of the catalysts for NO reduction [32], and the results are given in Table 3. The ratio of V5+ in the VMT catalyst was 67.6%, while it decreased to 59.2% in the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst, due to the electron migration between the doped Ni2+ and V5+ [36,37]. It should be noted that the V5+ sites were regarded as the acid sites for NH3 adsorption [37]. Therefore, the decrease of V5+ species could suppress the adsorption of NH3 and the activities of NO reduction over the modified VMT catalyst, which were consistent with the results in Sections 3.1.1 and 3.2.2. The XPS spectra of O 1s over the VMT and 40BiNi/VMT are shown in Fig. 13, in which the peak at 529.9 eV was assigned to lattice oxygen species (Oβ) and the peak at 531.0 eV was belonged to surface chemisorbed oxygen species (Oα) [25,38]. The ratios of Oα are given in Table 3. As can be seen, the ratio of Oα in the 40BiNi/VMT catalyst was much higher than that in the VMT catalyst. This confirmed that the loading of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides could significantly enhance the storage of chemisorbed oxygen over the VMT catalyst, which then facilitated the catalytic decomposition of N2O [39]. This agreed well with the results in Sections 3.1.1 and 3.2.3. 4 Conclusions A series of commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts modified with Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides were prepared by the impregnation method and further studied for the simultaneous removal of NO and N2O. It was found that the doping of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides could significantly promote the performance of N2O catalytic removal over commercial VMT catalyst in the temperature range of 300–420 °C, and the efficiency of NO removal could be kept over 90% with a promising stabliy for 10 h. Besides, the modified VMT catalyst possessed attractive water resistance ability, while the presence of NH3, O2 and SO2 inhibited the N2O decomposition. Based on the characterization results, the loaded Bi-Ni oxides could be kept as the stable NiO and Bi2O3 crystals over the VMT catalyst, which could block the micropores and increase the average pore size of the catalyst. The oxygen vacancies over the VMT catalyst were significantly enhanced because of the presence of Bi-Ni species, which facilitated the performance of N2O catalytic removal. Nevertheless, the doping of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides resulted in the decrease of V5+ species, which suppressed the adsorption of NH3 and decreased the efficiency of NO reduction over the modified VMT catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this study, a series of commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts modified with Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides were prepared and tested for NO and N2O simultaneous removal. It was found that the catalytic decomposition of N2O was dramatically promoted over the modified SCR catalyst with 40 wt% of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides, in which the efficiencies of NO and N2O removal were maintained over 90% and 80% respectively. Besides, the physical and chemical properties of the modified SCR catalyst were systematically characterized. It was confirmed that the doping of Bi-Ni mixed metal oxides could promote the oxygen vacancies over the surface of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst, thereby facilitating the decomposition of N2O. Whereas, the surface acid sites for NH3 adsorption and the ratio of V5+ was decreased remarkably with the presence of Bi-Ni species, which partly suppressed the activity of NO catalytic reduction.
coredata.dc:title: Simultaneous removal of NO and N2O over commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst modified with bismuth-nickel oxides
